turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Your husband is ill, ma'am. He took sick. I brought him home.

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: Why you?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I was at hand.

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: Well, thank you very much. You can go now.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: He needs me, ma'am.

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: No, he doesn't. And I don't want you here. Just go, please.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: He asked me to stay.

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: And I'm asking you -

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: This is not his handwriting.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: No. I was assisting him. He asked me.

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: He's not going to work on this anymore. It is making him ill. Please.

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: I regret we have no servants to show you out, Herr Salieri. Respect my wish and go.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Madame, I will respect his. He asked me to stay here.

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: How much will you pay him?

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Ah. Well. Ah,  I see you've got your manager with you. Well, Madame, how about half the receipts?

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Am I interrupting something?

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: Not at all.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Where's our friend?

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: He's not in. But he's working on it. He said to tell you.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: I hope so. I need it immediately.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Look, you little clown, do you know how many people I've hired for you? Do you know how many people are waiting?

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: Leave him alone!

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: I'm paying these people. Do you realize that?

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: He's doing his best.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: I'm paying people just to wait for you. It's ridiculous!

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: You know what's ridiculous? Your libretto, that's what's ridiculous. Only an idiot would ask Wolfi to work on that stuff!

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Oh yes? And what's so intelligent about writing a Requiem?

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: Money! Money!

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: You're mad! She's mad, Wolfi.

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: Oh yes, and who are you? He's worked for Kings. For the Emperor.  Who are you?

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: I see that you're expecting.

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: Oh, yes.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: When, may I ask?

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: In three months! Papa.

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: What is ridiculous? Wolfi has many admirers in Vienna. They love him here. People send us gifts all the time.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: But you can't take her without reference. It's unheard of!

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: Well, this is none of your business.  Whoever sent you is going to pay, no?

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: And so you do! The only time you come out is to eat.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: And what do you expect? Who wants to walk out into a mess like this every day?

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: Oh, now I'm a bad housekeeper!

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: So you are! The place is a pigsty all the time.

turns.speaker: CONSTANZE
turns.text: Do you hear him? Do you?

turns.speaker: FIRST LADY
turns.text: Be careful!

turns.speaker: SECOND LADY
turns.text: Be careful!

turns.speaker: FIRST LADY
turns.text: He's adorable!

turns.speaker: SECOND LADY
turns.text: Adorable!

turns.speaker: FIRST LADY
turns.text: Behold!

turns.speaker: SECOND LADY
turns.text: Behold!

turns.speaker: FIRST LADY
turns.text: Hey!

turns.speaker: SECOND LADY
turns.text: Hey!

turns.speaker: FIRST LADY
turns.text: Behold!

turns.speaker: SECOND LADY
turns.text: Behold!

turns.speaker: MADAME WEBER
turns.text: Let us pass, please! Let us pass at once! We're with the Emperor.

turns.speaker: FLUNKY
turns.text: I am sorry, Madame. It is not permitted.

turns.speaker: MADAME WEBER
turns.text: Do you know who I am?  This is my daughter. I am Frau Weber. We are favoured guests!

turns.speaker: FLUNKY
turns.text: I am sorry, Madame, but I have my orders.

turns.speaker: MADAME WEBER
turns.text: Call Herr Mozart! You call Herr Mozart immediately! This is insupportable!

turns.speaker: FLUNKY
turns.text: I am sorry, Madame, but no! I cannot let anyone pass.

turns.speaker: MADAME WEBER
turns.text: Young man, I am no stranger to theatres. I'm no stranger to insolence!

turns.speaker: FRAU SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Upstairs.

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Gertrude!

turns.speaker: FRAU SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: You can't be Herr Mozart!

turns.speaker: FRAU SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: I've heard about you for ages! I thought you must be an old man.

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Gertrude!

turns.speaker: FRAU SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: It's such an honour for us to have you here, Herr Mozart. And for Gertrude.

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: People who know say the girl's got talent. You must judge for yourself. If you think she stinks, say so.

turns.speaker: FRAU SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Michael, please! I'm sure you will find her most willing, Herr Mozart. She's really very excited. She's been preparing all morning.

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: I said play!

turns.speaker: FRAU SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Michael!

turns.speaker: FRAU SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: What a strange young man.

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Yes. He is a little strange.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: FRAU SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Ah, now! Here she comes.

turns.speaker: FRAU SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Perhaps a little refreshment first? A little coffee, or a little chocolate?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I'd like a little wine, if you have it.

turns.speaker: FRAU SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Wine?

turns.speaker: FRAU SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Just one year.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Who was your teacher?

turns.speaker: FRAU SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: I was. But she quite outgrew the little I could show her.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Thank you, Madame.  Come on now - courage. Play me something you know.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I think it is an interesting notion to keep Mozart in Vienna, Majesty. It should really infuriate the Archbishop beyond measure - if that is your Majesty's intention.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: You are cattivo, Court Composer.  I want to meet this young man. Chamberlain, arrange a pleasant welcome for him.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: What a charming idea. May I see?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: It's just a trifle, of course.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: May I try it?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Majesty.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Delightful, Court Composer. Would you permit me to play it as he comes in?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: You do me too much honour, Sire.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Let's have some fun.  Bring in Herr Mozart, please. But slowly, slowly. I need a minute to practice.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: A-flat, Majesty.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Ah-ha!

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: And here is our illustrious Court Composer, Herr Salieri.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Finally! Such an immense joy. Diletto straordinario!

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: My pleasure.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Well, there it is. Now to business. Young man, we are going to commission an opera from you. What do you say?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Well, I'm glad to hear that.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Excuse me, Sire, but what do you think these could be? Being a foreigner, I would love to learn.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Cattivo again, Court Composer. Well, tell him, Mozart. Name us a German virtue.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Good morning, Court Composer. This is my niece, the Princess Elizabeth.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Your Highness.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Oh, Your Majesty, it would be such a tremendous honour!

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: I'm thinking about Herr Mozart. What is your view?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: An interesting idea, Majesty. But -

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: You already commissioned an opera from Mozart.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: And the result satisfies.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes, of course. My concern is to protect you from any suspicion of favouritism.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Ah-ha. Favouritism. But I so want Mozart.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I'm sure there is a way, Majesty. Some kind of a little contest. I could perhaps put together a small Committee, and I could see to it naturally that it will select according to Your Majesty's wishes.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: You please me, Court Composer. A very clever idea.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Sire.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Well. There it is.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: I don't think you understand me, Court Composer.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Majesty, I did. Believe me, it was a most agonizing. decision. But finally, I simply could not recommend Herr Mozart.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Well, Sire, I made some inquiries in a routine way. I was curious to know why he had so few pupils. It is rather alarming.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Majesty, I don't like to talk against a fellow musician.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Of course not.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: I have to tell you, Mozart is not entirely to be trusted alone with young ladies.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: As a matter of fact, one of my own pupils - a very young singer - told me she was - er - well!

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Molested, Majesty. Twice, in the course of the same lesson.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Do you like this, Salieri?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: It is not a question of liking, Your Majesty. Your own law decrees it, I'm afraid.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Well, look at them.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Your Majesty!

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: No, no, please! It is not a holy relic.  You know we have met already? In this very room. Perhaps you won't remember it, you were only six years old.  He was giving the most brilliant little concert here. As he got off the stool, he slipped and fell. My sister Antoinette helped him up herself, and do you know what he did? Jumped straight into her arms and said, Will you marry me, yes or no?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Oh, thank you.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: The Director of our Opera. Count Orsini-Rosenberg.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Oh sir, yes! The honour is mine. Absolutely.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: And now he has returned the compliment. Herr Salieri composed that March of Welcome for you.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Really? Oh, grazie, Signore! Sono commosso! E un onore per mo eccezionale. Compositore brilliante e famossissimo!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Majesty!

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Did we vote in the end for German or Italian?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Why so?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Because I've already found the most wonderful libretto!

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Well, what is it about? Tell us the story.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: It's actually quite amusing, Majesty. It's set - the  whole thing is set in a - in a -

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Yes, where?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: In a Pasha's Harem, Majesty. A Seraglio.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Ah-ha.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Keep it, Sire, if you want to. It is already here in my head.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: What? On one hearing only?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I think so, Sire, yes.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: It is new, it is, isn't it, Sire?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Yes, indeed.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: And German?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Oh, yes. Absolutely. German. Unquestionably!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: So then you like it? You really like it, Your Majesty?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Of course I do. It's very good. Of course now and then - just now and then - it gets a touch elaborate.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: What do you mean, Sire?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Well, I mean occasionally it seems to have, how shall one say?  How shall one say, Director?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I don't understand. There are just as many notes, Majesty, as are required. Neither more nor less.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: My dear fellow, there are in fact only so many notes the ear can hear in the course of an evening. I think I'm right in saying that, aren't I, Court Composer?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: My dear, young man, don't take it too hard. Your work is ingenious. It's quality work. And there are simply too many notes, that's all. Cut a few and it will be perfect.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Which few did you have in mind, Majesty?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Majesty, this is Madame Weber. She is my landlady.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Enchanted, Madame.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Really? How delightful. May I ask when you marry?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Well - Well we haven't quite received my father's consent, Your Majesty. Not entirely. Not altogether.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Excuse me, but how old are you?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Twenty-six.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Well, my advice is to marry this charming young lady and stay with us in Vienna.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Bravo, Mozart. Most charming. Yes, indeed. Clever man.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Thank you, Sire!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Majesty, may I ask you to do me the greatest favour?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: May I introduce my father? He is on a short visit here and returning very soon to Salzburg. He would so much like to kiss your hand. It would make his whole stay so memorable for him.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Ah! By all means.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Mozart, are you aware I have declared the French play of Figaro unsuitable for our theatre?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Yes, Sire.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Yet we hear you are making an opera from it. Is this true?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Who told you this, Majesty?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: It is not your place to ask questions. Is it true?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Well, yes, I admit it is.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Would you tell me why?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Well, Majesty, it is only a comedy.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Mozart, I am a tolerant man. I do not censor things lightly. When I do, I have good reason. Figaro is a bad play. It stirs up hatred between the classes. In France it has caused nothing but bitterness. My own dear sister Antoinette writes me that she is beginning to be frightened of her own people. I do not wish to see the same fears starting here.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Sire, I swear to Your Majesty, there's nothing like that in the story. I have taken out everything that could give offense. I hate politics.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: I think you are rather innocent, my friend. In these dangerous times I cannot afford to provoke our nobles or our people simply over a theatre piece.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: But, Majesty, this is just a frolic. It's a piece about love.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Ah, love again.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: But it's new, it's entirely new. It's so new, people will go mad for it. For example, I have a scene in the second act - it starts as a duet, just a man and wife quarreling. Suddenly the wife's scheming little maid comes in unexpectedly - a very funny situation. Duet turns into trio. Then the husband's equally screaming valet comes in. Trio turns into quartet. Then a stupid old gardener - quartet becomes quintet, and so on.  On and on, sextet, septet, octet! How long do you think I can sustain that?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: I have no idea.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Guess! Guess, Majesty. Imagine the longest time such a thing could last, then double it.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Well, six or seven minutes! maybe eight!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Twenty, sire! How about twenty? Twenty minutes of continuous music. No recitatives.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Forgive me, Majesty. I'm a vulgar man. But I assure you, my music is not.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: You are passionate, Mozart! But you do not persuade.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Sire, the whole opera is finished. Do you know how much work went into it?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Ah-ha. Well then, we should make some effort to acquire him. We could use a good German composer in Vienna, surely?

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: I agree, Majesty, but I'm afraid it's not possible. The young man is still in the pay of the Archbishop.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Very small pay, I imagine. I'm sure he could be tempted with the right offer. Say, an opera in German for our National Theatre.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Ah-ha. What do you say, Chamberlain?

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: In my opinion, it is time we had a piece in our own language, sir. Plain German. For plain people.

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Well. There it is.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Well, what do you have for me today?

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: Your Majesty, Herr Mozart -

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Yes, what about him?

turns.speaker: VON STRACK
turns.text: He's here.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Ah-ha. Well. There it is. Good.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: I write to you with urgent news. I am coming to Vienna. Take no further steps toward marriage until we meet. You are too gullible to see your own danger. As you honour the father who has devoted his entire life to yours, do as I bid, and await my coming.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I will.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Why are you here?

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: Am I not welcome?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Of course, welcome! Welcome ten thousand times. Papa! my Papa!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Feed? Well, of course she feeds me. She stuffs me like a goose all day long. She's the best cook in the world. I mean, since Mama. Just wait, you'll see.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: Is she not here?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I don't know. Stanzi? Stanzi!

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: Do you always live like this?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Oh, yes. Oh, I mean no - not exactly like this. I mean today - just today, Stanzi - I remember now. She had to go - yes! She had to help her mother. Yes, she's like that. Her mother's a very sweet woman, you'll see.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: She's very tired, poor creature. You know me: I'm a real pig. It's not so easy cleaning up after me.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: Don't you have a maid?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Oh we could, if we wanted to, but Stanzi won't hear of it. She wants to do everything herself.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: How is your financial situation?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: It couldn't be better.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: That's not what I hear.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: What do you mean? It's wonderful. Really, it's - it's marvelous! People love me here.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: They say you're in debt.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Who? Who says that? Now that's a malicious lie!

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: How many pupils do you have?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Pupils?

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: How many?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I don't know. It's not important. I mean, I don't want pupils. They get in the way. I've got to have time for composition.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: Composition doesn't pay. You know that.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: This one will.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Oh, let's not talk about it.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: It's a secret.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: You don't have secrets from me.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: It's too dangerous, Papa. But they're going to love it. Ah, there she is!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Isn't that marvelous? We're delighted.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: Why didn't you mention it in your letters?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Didn't I? I thought I did. I'm sure I did.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: Thank you. That'll be fine. Don't spend any money on me.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Why not? Oh, come, Papa! What better way could I spend it than on you? My kissable, missable, suddenly visible Papa!

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: No, really!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: This is just a game, Papa.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Yes, Papa, name it. Name it. I'll do anything you say!

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: I want you to come back with me to Salzburg, my son.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: I'm tired of this game. Please play without me.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: But my penalty. I've got to have a penalty.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Papa, is this your idea?

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: Mine?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Are you playing a trick on me?

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: I never saw this girl in my life.  Is this a kind of joke?

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: Never mind. You won't have to do anything for me ever again. I'm leaving!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Papa!

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: Don't worry, I'm not staying here to be a burden.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: No one calls you that.

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: She does. She says I sleep all day.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Father -

turns.speaker: LEOPOLD
turns.text: Hush! I'm talking to His Majesty. Your Majesty, I wish to express only one thing - that you who are the Father of us all, could teach our children the gratitude they owe to fathers. It is not for nothing that the Fifth Commandment tells us: 'Honour your Father and Mother, that your days may be long upon the earth.'

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Ah! Here she comes. Fraulein Lorl, good morning.

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: Good morning, sir.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: What have you got for me today? Let me see.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Ah-ha! Siena macaroons - my favourites. Give my best thanks to the baker.

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: I will, sir.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Thank you. Are you well today, Fraulein Lorl?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: Yes, thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Bene! Bene!

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: Madame Cavalieri is here for her lesson, sir.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Bene.

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: Oh, thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Do any pupils come to the house?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: Not that I've seen.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Then how does he pay for all this? Does he work at all?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: Oh, yes, sir, all day long. He never leaves the house until evening. He just sits there, writing and writing. He doesn't even eat.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Really? What is it he's writing?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: Oh, I wouldn't know that, sir.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Of course not. You're a good girl. You're very kind to do this. Next time you're sure they'll be out of the house, let me know, will you?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: I think I've found out about the money, sir.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Yes what?

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Where does he work?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: In there, sir.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Now calm yourself. Calm. What's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: I'm leaving. I'm not working there anymore. I'm scared!

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Why? What has happened?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: You don't know what it's like. Herr Mozart frightens me. He drinks all day, then takes all that medicine and it makes him worse.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: What medicine?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: I don't know. He has pains.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: Here, in his stomach. They bend him right over.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Is he working?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: I'm frightened, sir. Really! When he speaks, he doesn't make any sense. You know he said he saw - he said he saw his father. And his father's dead.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Is he working?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: I suppose so. He sits there all he time, doing some silly opera.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Opera? Opera!

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: Please don't ask me to go back again. I'm frightened! I'm very, very frightened.

turns.speaker: SALIERI
turns.text: Are you sure it's an opera?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: Are you Herr Mozart?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: My name is Lorl, sir. I'm a maidservant. I was asked to come here and offer my services to you.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: They'll be paid for by a great admirer or yours who wishes to remain anon - anonymous.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Are you saying that someone is paying you to be our maid and doesn't want us to know who he is?

turns.speaker: LORL
turns.text: Yes. I can live in or out just as you wish.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Sssh!

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Stanzi-Manzi-Banzi-Wanzi!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Sssh! Stay here.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: What did he say? What did he say?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Papa, the rule is you can only give penalties that can be performed in the room.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Sublime! Utterly sublime!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: That kind of music should be punishable by death.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Wonderful!  He liked the monkey, didn't you?

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Yes, well, it's all good fun.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I liked the horse.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Isn't he marvelous? He cost me a bundle, that horse, but he's worth it. I tell you, if you'd played Don Giovanni here it would have been a great success. I'm not joking. These people aren't fools. You could do something marvelous for them.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I'd like to try them someday. I'm not sure I'd be much good at it.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: 'Course you would. You belong here, my boy, not the snobby Court. You could do anything you felt like here - the more fantastic the better! That's what people want, you know: fantasy. You do a big production, fill it with beautiful magic tricks and you'll be absolutely free to do anything you want. Of course, you'd have to put a fire in it, because I've got the best fire machine in the city and a big flood - I can do you the finest water effects you ever saw in your life. Oh, and a few trick animals. You'd have to use those.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Animals?

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: I tell you I picked up a snake in Dresden last week - twelve foot long  - folds up to six inches, just like a paper fan. It's a miracle.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: I'm serious. You write a proper part for me with a couple of catchy songs, I'll guarantee you'll have a triumph- de-luxe. Mind you, it'll have to be in German.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: German!

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Of course! What else do you think they speak here?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: No, no, I love that. I'd want it to be in German. I haven't done anything in German since Seraglio.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: So there you are. What do you say?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Leave that alone!

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Wolfi!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Put it down!

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: What is this?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Put it down, I said! It's nothing for you.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Oh! I'm sorry! I'm sorry! What have you got for me? Is it finished?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: What? The vaudeville, what'd you think?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Can I see it?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Because there's nothing to see.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: Look, I asked you if we could start rehearsal next week and you said yes.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Well, we can.

turns.speaker: SCHIKANEDER
turns.text: So let me see it. Where is it?

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Quiet! Quiet! Quiet! Down there, damn you.  Welcome to you. Pay no attention, they're impossible. Stop it, you willful things! Come this way. Just ignore them. They're perfectly harmless, just willful. I treat them just like my own children.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: And which one of them do you want me to teach?

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: What? Ha-ha! That's funny - I like it. Which one, eh? You're a funny fellow.  Hannah! Come this way.

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: You won't be teaching this one either. She's my wife.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Madame.

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: This is Herr Mozart, my dear. The young man Herr Salieri recommended to teach our Gertrude. Where is she?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: I'm afraid I am.

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Of course, it's him. Who do you think it is?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Good morning, Fraulein Schlumberg.

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Strudel, this is Herr Mozart. Say good morning.

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Never mind, Strudel. It's part of music, getting used to an audience. Aren't I right, Herr Mozart?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Well, yes! on the whole. I suppose.  How long have you been playing, Fraulein?

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: It's a miracle, Herr Mozart!

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Well, I'm a good teacher. The next time you wish me to instruct another of your dogs, please let me know. Goodbye, Fraulein, goodbye, Madame! goodbye, Sir!

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Herr Mozart. What a surprise. What can I do for you?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Is my pupil still anxious to learn the art of music?

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Well, your pupil is married and living in Mannheim, young man.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Really? Perhaps your dear wife might care to profit from my instruction?

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: What is this, Mozart? What's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: Well. Since it appears nobody is eager to hire my services, could you favour me with a little money instead?

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: If a man cannot earn, he must borrow.

turns.speaker: SCHLUMBERG
turns.text: Well, this is hardly the way to go about it.

turns.speaker: MOZART
turns.text: No doubt, sir. But I am endowed with talent, and you with money. If I offer mine, you should offer yours.
